channel.title: Python on BMMB554
channel.description: Recent content in Python on BMMB554

item.title: Lecture 8: Plotting in Python
item.description: This lecture draws extensively from Seaborn tutorials. A primer of plotting with Python # If running in colaboratory uncomment and run the folliwing command #!pip install seaborn --upgradeimport seaborn as sns sns.set(style="ticks") import pandas as pd import matplotlib.pyplot as plt Why plotting? We will use Ascombe’s quartet build into Seaborn to answer this questions # Load the example dataset for Anscombe's quartet df = sns.load_dataset("anscombe")df .dataframe tbody tr th:only-of-type { vertical-align: middle; } .

item.title: Lecture 7: Pandas 2
item.description: Prep Point your browser to http://colab.research.google.com Open notebook 2019/ipynb/tnseq_with_pandas2.ipynb from https://github.com/nekrut/BMMB554 Introduction to Pandas : Part 2 This tutorial is heavily based on Pandas in 10 min. The original material waas modified by adding TnSeq data as examples. import pandas as pd import numpy as np %matplotlib inline Get datasets to play with %%bash wget https://nekrut.github.io/BMMB554/tnseq_untreated.txt.gz wget https://nekrut.github.io/BMMB554/ta_gc.txtdata_file = 'tnseq_untreated.txt.gz'# Just two choices for beginning of of gene field !

item.title: Lecture 6: Pandas 1
item.description: Prep Point your browser to http://colab.research.google.com Open notebook 2019/ipynb/tnseq_with_pandas.ipynb from https://github.com/nekrut/BMMB554 Introduction to Pandas : Part 1 This tutorial is heavily based on Pandas in 10 min. The original material waas modified by adding TnSeq data as examples. Get datasets to play with %%bash wget https://nekrut.github.io/BMMB554/tnseq_untreated.txt.gz wget https://nekrut.github.io/BMMB554/ta_gc.txt2019-01-28 13:53:53 (2.53 MB/s) - 'tnseq_untreated.txt.gz' saved [2012967/2012967] 2019-01-28 13:53:56 (2.96 MB/s) - 'ta_gc.txt' saved [7315570/7315570] data_file = 'tnseq_untreated.txt.gz' The first dataset lists coordinates of TA sites and counts of reads for TnSeq constructs ‘blunt’, ‘cap’, ‘dual’, ‘erm’, ‘pen’, and ‘tuf’:

item.title: Lecture 5: NumPy
item.description: Prep Point your browser to http://colab.research.google.com Open notebook 2019/ipynb/numpy.ipynb from https://github.com/nekrut/BMMB554 Numpy: Operations with multidimensional data This notebook is based (with some modifications) on a NumPy tutorial by J.R. Johansson # Import MatPlotlib so we can look at some pretty plots # The reson for doing this will become clear in out MatPlotLib lecture next week %matplotlib inline import matplotlib.pyplot as plt Introduction The numpy package (module) is used in almost all numerical computation using Python.

item.title: Lecture 4: Python refresher 2
item.description: Conditionals, Loops, and Files This material is heavily inspired by Materials for the course run by the Graduate School of Life Sciences, University of Cambridge with some modifications. Let’s get started Point your browser to http://colab.research.google.com Open notebook 2019/ipynb/intro2.ipynb from https://github.com/nekrut/BMMB554 Case study: Transposon insertion sequencing (TnSeq) Transposon insertion allows genome-wide identification of essential genes. The idea is simple = important genes cannot be disrupted and there will not accept any transposon insertions.

item.title: Lecture 3: Python refresher 1
item.description: What is Python? Python is a modern, general-purpose, object-oriented, high-level programming language. This material is heavily inspired by Materials for the course run by the Graduate School of Life Sciences, University of Cambridge with some modifications. General characteristics of Python: Clean and Simple: Easy-to-read and intuitive code, easy-to-learn minimalistic syntax, maintainability scales well with size of projects. Expressive: Fewer lines of code, fewer bugs, easier to maintain.

item.title: Lecture 2: Basic machinery = Jupyter + GitHub
item.description: Welcome to Notebooks An important assumption for this lecture is that (1) you have a Google account, (2) know how to use Google Drive, and (3) also have an active GitHub account. When you start an analysis, you don’t really know how it will go. Maybe data is bad and there is no real reason to analyze anything at all. Maybe data data outliers that need to be dealt with.
